segments.text: Yes, we had, like I say, the congressmen and the people that control the purse strings telling the military that they had to conduct a war a certain way.
If you're going to win a war, you've got to do whatever means are available to you to win that war.
In Vietnam, the Viet Cong and the North Vietnamese Army, once they found that they were
being defeated, they would retreat into either Cambodia or north of Vietnam.
The U.S. military did not have the authority to attack them in these places.
Once they retreated, they could not be followed.
Once they retreated, they couldn't be bombed.
We were, and when I say we, I'm talking about the Congress and a lot of your general public
wanted to fight a war with world opinion on our side.
We were not allowed to bomb North Vietnam, even though Hanoi was at different times bombed.
This could only be done on certain times.
What I'm saying is the military was trying to fight a war with one hand tied behind its back.
The military takes their professionalism serious.
However, when their authority is questioned daily, their ability to conduct a war becomes very, very limited.
That is one of the reasons that we lost the war and more than likely
A large percentage of the reasons.
Another reason that I feel that contributed significantly to the losing the war effort was the
general soldier's attitude towards the war, even though I've mentioned on several occasions that the average soldier going over there was a volunteer, and he did it because it was a thing to do.
He did it for professional reasons.
The military afforded him the opportunity to lose a lot of that sense of professionalism.
in Vietnam, as opposed to World War Two, where a person would go for the duration of the war.
In Vietnam, the soldier was sent over for a 12 month period of time on a tour.
The majority of us
went over with the impression that we're going to be there for one year.
We are going to become back after a year because it never entered our mind that we were going over there to be killed.
We knew that we were going over there to fight a war.
Some even anticipated going over there to war.
They looked forward to it, not really knowing what they were going to encounter other than maybe what they saw in the movies or on television.
And again, it was one of those things where they were not going to be the ones killed.
It was always going to happen to somebody else.
We went over there with the impression anyhow that we were going to be over there for a year.
And we weren't very professional about it.
Every soldier, or a great number of soldiers, would go out and get drunk just about every night.
Beer was prevalent in Vietnam.
wasn't available in the economy, the military made great effort to bring beer out to the soldiers, even close to the war zone.
I think I can honestly say that the beer itself was not brought out to the battle line.
However, war was not being fought
24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
It was being fought during short periods of time where, after the battle, the soldier would return to a garrison environment.
The garrison environment had a lot of beer in it, either right there in the military compound or off the military compound.
Whenever a soldier, a person, drains excessively and suffers from a withdrawal, a hangover, his proficiency, his sufficiency is going to diminish.
Consequently, I think that drugs, even though, like I mentioned, during my period of time, the hard drugs were not there.
However, they were prevalent throughout the latter half of the Vietnam War.
I think that drugs had a big thing to do about losing the war.
Also of major significance, I think,
was the lack of respect that we got from the Vietnamese.
Like I mentioned, this was a guerrilla type of a war.
If you're going to win a war like that, you have to have the general populace
the indigent support.
If you do not have their support, then you might as well pack it up and go home.
We did not respect the Vietnamese.
We didn't like the Vietnamese.
I am sure that they did not respect us.
More than likely, they didn't like us.
They liked our money, but they did not support us.
They had a bigger propaganda effort
They had a public figure, Ho Chi Minh, who they all respected to look up to.
We could provide them with nothing.
Even their elected, and they were not elected, even their government was not well liked.
So consequently, when we did not receive the public support, the Viet Cong found it easy, and so did the North Vietnamese Army, to hide within the general populace.
The general population did not provide us with the information because they supported the opposing side.
This had a big thing to do with us losing the war.
Those three things are the military having to fight a war with one hand tied behind their back, the drugs, and the lack of support by the local, national, of the Republic of Vietnam.
I'd like to thank you for sharing your experiences with me.
In closing, would you like to add any remarks?
Only that I'd like to say that what I have said is things that I have, are personal experiences that my thoughts do not necessarily are the thoughts
of any other person.
These are things that I picked up from personal experience that I picked up from my observations.
I want to thank you for letting me conduct this interview and I hope that we do not have to suffer one of these experiences again.
Thank you.
